div.p: This plugin allows users to interact with the Internet Information Services (IIS) server and accomplish tasks such as managing servers, web sites and virtual directories.

Supported IIS version
This plugin was developed and tested with IIS 6.0.
To enable Commander to communicate with your IIS installation, create a IIS configuration, supplying the following information:

ul.li: Configuration Name - Provide a unique name for the configuration, keeping in mind that you may need to create additional configurations over time.
IIS IP Address - Provide the URL for the IIS server, it must include the protocol and port (example: http://192.168.1.100).
IIS Port - Provide the port for the IIS server (example: 8081).
Computer Name - Provide the computer name or IP address without backslashes (for example: server01 or 192.168.1.100).

Credential - Provide the username and password for the IIS server. NOTE: Credentials are optional. Supplying credentials for a "local" agent (an agent on the same machine as the IIS server) is unnecessary, and in some cases will generate a 'warning' condition.
IIS Version - Select the compatibility mode for IIS version to be used (NOTE: currently, only IIS 6 is supported; IIS 7 will be added in the near future).

div.p: See the Commander online help systemfor details about how to use this plugin within a procedure.
Checks the status of the specified server.

ul.li: configname - Provide the name of the configuration that holds connection information for the IIS server. In this case, only credentials are taken from the configuration.
usecredentials - Indicate if credentials must be used.

div.p: Creates a new virtual directory in the specified web site.

ul.li: absolutephysicalpath - Provide the absolute physical path assigned to the virtual directory you want to create.
configname - Provide the name of the configuration that holds connection information for the IIS server.
execpath - Provide the absolute path of the script utility used to execute this step (for example: iisvdir or c:/windows/system32/iisvdir.vbs).
virtualdirname - Provide the name for the virtual directory.
virtualpath - Provide a path, if necessary, to the virtual directory within the web site.
website - Provide the descriptive name, or the metabase path, of the web site of the virtual directory you want to create.

div.p: Deletes a virtual directory in the specified web site.

ul.li: configname - Provide the name of the configuration that holds connection information for the IIS server.
execpath - Provide the absolute path of the script utility used to execute this step (for example: iisvdir or c:/windows/system32/iisvdir.vbs).
virtualdirname - Provide the name for the virtual directory.
virtualpath - Provide a path, if necessary, to the virtual directory within the web site of the virtual directory you want to delete.
website - Provide the descriptive name, or the metabase path, of the web site of the virtual directory you want to delete.

div.p: Creates a web site configuration on a local or remote computer.

ul.li: absolutephysicalpath - Provide the absolute physical path assigned to the web site you want to create.
configname - Provide the name of the configuration that holds connection information for the IIS server.
execpath - Provide the absolute path of the script utility used to execute this step (for example: iisweb or c:/windows/system32/iisweb.vbs).
hostheader - Provide the host header name for the web site.
startapp - Indicate if web site must be started after creation.
website - Provide the descriptive name, or the metabase path, of the web site you want to create.

div.p: Copies the application files recursively to the website application's physical directory.

ul.li: ExecPath - Relative or absolute path to the XCOPY (or similar) executable
SourcePath - Path to the source directory
DestinationPath - Path to the destination directory. This must be a physical directory, but it may have an IIS virtual directory pointing to it.

AdditionalOptions - Option switches to the XCOPY executable, excluding source and destination directories. The default options are those recommended by Microsoft for ASP.NET and IIS Website deployment; change these with caution.
/E - Deep copy including empty dirs
/K - Copy attributes
/R - Overwrite read-only files
/H - Copy hidden and system files
/I - If destination does not exist and copying more than one file, assumes that destination must be a directory.
/Y - Supress prompting for overwrite confirmation

div.p: Fetches the numeric internal IIS identifiers of all Web Sites found on the host server. These IDs are necessary to access internal webite properties in order to perform certain control operations. The IDs are saved into Job Properties under the "iiswebsites" property sheet, with the web site name as the property name and the WebSiteID as the value. If the this procedure is run prior to other procedures which require a WebSiteID, you can use the property $[/myJob/iiswebsites/sitename] as the parameter value.

ul.li: HostName - The host name of the IIS Server (if the procedure is run on the host itself use "localhost", the default value).

div.p: Returns the current state of the site. The state is also saved in a Job Property under the "sitestatus" property sheet, with the web site name as the property name and the numeric status code as the value. The possible status values are: 1 (starting), 2 (started), 3 (stopping), 4 (stopped), 5 (pausing), 6 (paused), or 7 (continuing).

ul.li: HostName - The host name of the IIS Server (if the procedure is run on the host itself use "localhost", the default value).

WebSiteID - The WebSiteID parameter must be the numeric internal identifier from the server's MetaBase information. The default value is 1, which is the ID of the "Default Web Site" set up with the IIS installation. See the GetWebSiteIDs procedure to get the WebSiteID parameter value from the site name. NOTE: The ID of a Web Site can be found in the IIS Manager GUI (sort of). Open the Properties dialog of a web site and click on the "Properties" button in the Logging section at the bottom of the dialog. Look at the name of the log file at the bottom of that Logging Properties dialog: the site ID number follows the letters "W3SVC".

div.p: Returns basic information for all Virtual Directories defined for the web site (recursively). This procedure is primarily for informational purposes rather than any specific controls.

ul.li: HostName - The host name of the IIS Server (if the procedure is run on the host itself use "localhost", the default value).

WebSiteID - The WebSiteID parameter must be the numeric internal identifier from the server's MetaBase information. The default value is 1, which is the ID of the "Default Web Site" set up with the IIS installation. See the GetWebSiteIDs procedure to get the WebSiteID parameter value from the site name. NOTE: The ID of a Web Site can be found in the IIS Manager GUI (sort of). Open the Properties dialog of a web site and click on the "Properties" button in the Logging section at the bottom of the dialog. Look at the name of the log file at the bottom of that Logging Properties dialog: the site ID number follows the letters "W3SVC".
